channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Ahead of India-Pakistan Talks, Militants Kill as Many as 12 in Indian-Controlled Kashmir
item.description: Three men dressed in Indian Army uniforms attacked a police station and an army base, officials said, just days before a planned meeting between leaders of India and Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Army soldiers taking up positions during a militant attack on an army camp in Samba district in Jammu and Kashmir, on Thursday.

item.title: Court Upholds 50-Year Jail Term in Sierra Leone War Crimes Case
item.description: Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, had appealed a 50-year sentence imposed last year in a case seen as a watershed for modern human rights law.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS and ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Koen Van Weel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Charles G. Taylor in court on Thursday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: Sept. 26
item.description: According to a recent report by the local authorities in New Delhi, cases of dengue fever are on a rise in the city.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A worker from the Municipal Corporation of Delhi, or M.C.D., fumigating a residential area in New Delhi to prevent mosquitoes from breeding. Dengue fever, a mosquito-borne disease, is on the rise in the city according to a recent M.C.D. report.

item.title: Divers Find Human Remains Near Italian Shipwreck
item.description: Divers spotted human remains Thursday near Italy's Costa Concordia cruise ship and DNA tests will determine if they are the last two bodies missing among the shipwreck's 32 victims, authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Russian Court Orders Greenpeace Activists Held
item.description: A Russian court on Thursday ordered two Greenpeace activists and a photographer accompanying their team to be jailed for two months pending an investigation of a protest at an Arctic oil platform.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Letter From Europe: A Challenge to European Political Elite
item.description: Across the Continent, small protest parties are exerting a disproportionate pull on national political life, to the detriment of larger and more established parties.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Chinese Provinces Collect Billions in Family Planning Fines, Lawyer Says
item.description: The lawyer said he suspected that the fines, for violating laws that usually limit couples to one child, were a substantial source of revenue for some provinces.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Bomb Attacks at Markets in, Near Baghdad Kill 23
item.description: Bombs ripped through outdoor markets in and near Baghdad on Thursday, killing at least 23 people and wounding dozens, the latest in a deadly wave that has hit Iraq in recent months, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Report Warns of Chinese Municipal Debt Risks
item.description: Nomura analysts say local governments increased their debt by nearly 40 percent in 2011 and 2012, creating systemic dangers.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER

item.title: India Ink: Can Urban Planning Help India’s Cities Reduce Sexual Violence ?
item.description: Urban planners and designers argue that apart from better policing, gender-sensitive city planning and design can help make India’s cities safer for women.
item.dc:creator: By NEYAZ FAROOQUEE
item.media:description: Vehicles moving along a busy road in New Delhi on Nov. 9, 2011.

item.title: Chinese Court Sentences Celebrity Singer’s Son to 10 Years for Rape
item.description: Li Tianyi, 17, and four other defendants were convicted in a case that stirred discussion about the reckless lives of some offspring of China’s elite.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Arms Treaty Now Signed by Majority of U.N. Members
item.description: The United States and 17 other countries officially signed the treaty aimed at regulating the global trade in conventional weapons.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Tech Giants Fear Spread of Patent Wars to Europe
item.description: After spending hundreds of millions of dollars in the United States to defend patent-infringement lawsuits, the companies worry that Europe could become a similar battleground.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: The Paris office of Google, which is concerned about a proposed change in the European Union’s patent court system.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: For the U.N., Syria Is Both Promise and Peril
item.description: The American-Russian agreement to rid Syria of chemical weapons should please — and terrify — anyone hoping to see the United Nations return to relevance in global security.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NADER MOUSAVIZADEH

item.title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged With Role in 2 Deaths in Pakistan
item.description: Mohammad Ajmal Choudhry is accused of conspiring to kill relatives of people who he believed had helped his daughter flee an arranged marriage.
item.dc:creator: By MOSI SECRET

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How Do You Say ‘Blog’ in German?
item.description: The editors of the German Duden dictionary added 5,000 words to the 26th edition, many of them English or of English origin. Some Germans aren’t happy.
item.dc:creator: By ANNA SAUERBREY

item.title: Iran’s Leader, Denouncing Holocaust, Stirs Dispute
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani’s condemnation of the Holocaust has set off a political storm, landing him in precisely the kind of tangled dispute he had hoped to avoid.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran addressing the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday. He walks a delicate tightrope, trying to calm hard-liners at home.

item.title: Key Syrian Rebel Groups Abandon Exile Leaders
item.description: As diplomats push for a peace conference to end Syria’s conflict, a collection of some of the country’s most powerful rebel groups have publicly abandoned the opposition’s political leaders.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Smoke rose after an airstrike in a village in Hama Province on Wednesday.

item.title: Turkish Protesters Are Still Said to Be Ailing From Tear Gas
item.description: Almost 40 percent of protesters surveyed by a Turkish medical group complained of continuing repercussions from their exposure to the tear gas used in last spring’s antigovernment demonstrations, the group says.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: U.N. Official Calls for War Crimes Inquiry
item.description: The official said she “detected no new or comprehensive effort to independently or credibly investigate the allegations” that civilians were killed by the military.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: In Indonesia, a Governor at Home on the Streets
item.description: As Indonesians look to their next presidential election, many are talking about a local governor who has demonstrated an unusually common touch with the people.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Rony Zakaria for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Joko Widodo, the governor of Jakarta, made an unannounced visit to the Tanah Abang market in August, where he is a frequent visitor.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Over 100,000 Displaced Face Disease
item.description: The United Nations said Wednesday that those displaced by two weeks of fighting between soldiers and Muslim rebels are at risk of disease from unsanitary conditions in evacuation centers.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Attacks in Iraq Kill at Least 25
item.description: Attackers detonated three car bombs on the local council building in Hawija before fighting security forces for an hour, an army commander said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Sees Direct Threat in Attack at Kenya Mall
item.description: Dozens of F.B.I. agents are investigating the wreckage, hoping to glean every piece of information possible to help prevent such a devastating attack from happening again, possibly even on American soil.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Foreign forensic experts and Kenyan military personnel combed the exterior of the Westgate mall on Wednesday.

item.title: Oscar Espinosa Chepe, Cuban Economist and Critic of Castro, Dies at 72
item.description: Mr. Espinosa Chepe, who advocated the limited restoration of capitalist principles, remained in Cuba despite enduring harassment and imprisonment.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
